channel.title: NYT > U.S.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Keeping Grip on Data Pipeline, Obama Does Little to Reassure Industry
item.description: While President Obama bolstered some protections for citizens, he did nothing, at least yet, to address the data security concerns of U.S. technology companies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER
item.media:description: President Obama on Friday announced changes in a contentious surveillance program that has swept up many millions of records of Americans’ cellphone calls, though not their content.

item.title: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
item.description: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: President Obama set out his policies on surveillance by the government in a speech at the Justice Department on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,291 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Sneaky Path Into Target Customers’ Wallets
item.description: An examination by The New York Times into an enormous data theft shows that Target’s system was particularly vulnerable to attack.
item.dc:creator: By ELIZABETH A. HARRIS, NICOLE PERLROTH, NATHANIEL POPPER and HILARY STOUT
item.media:description: Shoppers at a Target store during a sale on Thanksgiving Day. Data from as many as 110 million customers is believed to have been stolen.

item.title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Boy, 4, Is Killed by Girl, 4, Who Found a Gun
item.description: A 4-year-old girl accidentally shot her 4-year-old cousin to death with a loaded rifle that she found under a bed at their grandfather’s Detroit home, the police said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Court Upholds Sex Change for Inmate
item.description: A federal appeals court has upheld a ruling requiring the State Department of Corrections to provide gender reassignment surgery for an inmate serving a life sentence for murdering his wife.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: National Briefing | Washington: Bloomberg to Push G.O.P. for Immigration Action
item.description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in Washington on Friday to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up an overhaul of immigration laws.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER

item.title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: 2 Shot at School
item.description: A boy and girl talking with other students in a Philadelphia high school gym were shot and wounded Friday, and up to three boys may have been involved in the shooting, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Judge Blocks Ultrasound Requirement
item.description: A federal judge on Friday declared unconstitutional the state’s ultrasound requirement for women seeking abortions, saying it violated the First Amendment by requiring doctors to display a fetal image and describe it even to women who covered their eyes and ears.
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM

item.title: After a Prolonged Execution in Ohio, Questions Over ‘Cruel and Unusual’
item.description: At a time when the drugs used in executions are in short supply, an execution in Ohio has raised questions about the obligations of the state toward those it kills.
item.dc:creator: By ERICA GOODE
item.media:description: Amber McGuire, left, recounted the execution of her father, Dennis McGuire, alongside her sister-in-law Missie McGuire at a news conference Friday in Dayton, Ohio.

item.title: Keeping Wide Net, Obama Sets Limits on Phone Spying
item.description: President Obama, responding on Friday to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, said he would require intelligence agencies to get court permission before tapping into a vast trove of phone data.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: In the front row at Mr. Obama's speech were his top security officials, from left to right: F.B.I. Director James B. Comey, C.I.A. Director John Brennan, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson.

item.title: Two Senators Have Little but a State in Common
item.description: Tammy Baldwin, a Democrat, and Ron Johnson, a Republican, of Wisconsin personify the polarized Congress, voting against each other more than any other state’s senators.
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: “You know, we’re not best buds,” said Ron Johnson, a Republican, of his fellow senator from Wisconsin, Tammy Baldwin, a Democrat, although he characterized their acquaintance as respectful.

item.title: Typography Partners Part Ways in Money Fight
item.description: Tobias Frere-Jones, in a lawsuit filed late, accused Jonathan Hoefler of luring him to the company in 1999 with the false promise that they would be 50-50 partners.
item.dc:creator: By NOAM COHEN
item.media:description: Tobias Frere-Jones, left, and Jonathan Hoefler gave Barack Obama’s presidential campaign a distinctive look.

item.title: Defendant Admits Sending Letter With Ricin to Obama
item.description: J. Everett Dutschke, who mailed poison-tainted letters to public officials including President Obama, pleaded guilty to four counts in Oxford, Miss.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN BLINDER
item.media:description: J. Everett Dutschke in Tupelo, Miss., last year. His agreement with prosecutors calls for a 25-year prison sentence.

item.title: More Details in Mistaken Landing of a Plane
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board said it had interviewed the pilots of a Southwest Airlines flight that landed at the wrong airport this week.
item.dc:creator: By JAD MOUAWAD

item.title: Standstill on Farm Bill May Revive 1949 Rules
item.description: Lawmakers have until the end of the month to reach agreement on a new farm bill and halt 1949 policies that could cause the cost of milk double.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Supreme Court Will Consider Whether Police Need Warrants to Search Cellphones
item.description: The case centers on the wide variety and personal nature of information on today’s smartphones.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: The Lede: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
item.description: The accounts were used by the militant wing of the Palestinian government to directly communicate with the Israel Defense Forces during at 2012 bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of an exchange between an Israeli military spokesman and the military wing of Hamas on Twitter in October.

item.title: Company in West Virginia Spill Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: Freedom Industries, whose chemical spill last week in West Virginia tainted the drinking water of more than 300,000 residents in and around Charleston, is seeking Chapter 11 protection.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES
item.media:description: A storage tank with the designation for the chemical that leaked at the Freedom Industries storage facility in Charleston, W.Va.

item.title: The Lede: Marine Corps Apologizes for Gunman Reference in Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday Tweet
item.description: The Marine Corps Special Operations Command apologized on Friday for a Tweet that appeared to make light of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., urging its followers not to be a “lone shooter” over the holiday weekend. Dr. King was assassinated by a gunman in 1968.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: On Friday the official Twitter account of the Marine Corps Special Operation Command posted a joke about the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., urging its followers not to be a "lone shooter" over the holiday weekend. Dr. King was assassinated by a gunman in 1968.

item.title: News Analysis: A Crucial Caveat in Obama’s Vow on Phone Data
item.description: President Obama left the “end” of the bulk telephone data program to another day in a speech partly intended to convince the public that spy programs are being run appropriately.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Pennsylvania Voter ID Law Struck Down as Judge Cites Burden on Citizens
item.description: A judge said the law placed an unreasonable burden on people trying to exercise their fundamental right to vote.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Congressional Memo: Years Before His Bipartisan Luster, a Rough Reception for Gates
item.description: Strong criticism of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. by former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates recalls his tough battles with Congress in 1987 and 1991 over his nomination as C.I.A. director.
item.dc:creator: By CARL HULSE

item.title: Severe Drought Grows Worse in California
item.description: The problem is visible from the Sierra Nevada to the farmlands in the southern part of the state, and it threatens to cause major hardship.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and MALIA WOLLAN
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Folsom Lake in California, which is at 17 percent of capacity, the marina sits on dry land and an abandoned town from the 19th century has resurfaced.

item.title: The ‘No More Tears’ Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde
item.description: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.
item.dc:creator: By KATIE THOMAS
item.media:credit: Laura Pedrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Johnson & Johnson's decision to reformulate its baby products is the first step in an effort to remove an array of increasingly unpopular chemicals from its personal care products.
